bestBHT.bht: In this scene, Jesus reveals the inspiration of the prophetic Scriptures, ending the Pharisees' attempts to trap Him. David, under the influence of the Holy Spirit, designates the Messiah as Lord, implying superiority. By connecting the phrase in spirit with the word call, it becomes clear that David saw more in the Messiah than just a human descendant. This challenges the belief that Jesus is solely the son of David, affirming his divine nature and authority.

Henry Alford: This is a weighty declaration by our Lord of the inspiration of the prophetic Scriptures."
Here then end the endeavours of His adversaries to entrap Him by questions: they now betake themselves to other means."
A new scene, as it were, henceforth opens.
John Calvin: By this phrase he anticipates the sophistry by which the Jews of the present day attempt to escape.
It is because David, who was king and head of the people, calls him Lord; from which it follows, that there is something in him greater than man.
But, according to the testimony of Paul, when Christ was raised to kingly power, there was given to him a name which is above every name, that before him every knee should bow.
Philip Schaff: How then doth David in the Spirit, i.e., by the inspiration of the Holy Ghost.
Call him Lord. Solemnly designate Him thus, implying superiority.
John Gill: if he is a mere man, if he is only the son of David, according to the flesh, if he has no other, or higher descent than from him, how comes it to pass, that David, under the inspiration of the Spirit of God, by which he wrote his book of Psalms, see 2 Samuel 23:1 where the passage, after cited, stands, to call him Lord
which supposes him to be more than barely his son, and to be a greater person than himself, one superior in nature and dignity to him?

the phrase 'in spirit', is not to be connected with the word Lord; as if the design of it was to show, that the Messiah was Lord, or God, in spirit, or with respect to his divine nature, but, with the word 'call', expressing the influence of the Spirit of God, under which David wrote
John Wesley: How doth David then by the Spirit — By inspiration, call him Lord?"
If he be merely the son (or descendant) of David?"
If he be, as you suppose, a mere man, the son of a man?

bhtAttempts.bht: This declaration by our Lord in Matthew 22:43 highlights the inspiration of the prophetic Scriptures. It marks the end of the Pharisees' attempts to trap Jesus with questions and introduces a new scene. David, under the inspiration of the Holy Ghost, calls the Messiah Lord, implying superiority. The phrase in spirit is not to be connected with the word Lord to prove the divinity of the Messiah, but rather shows the influence of the Spirit of God under which David wrote. Therefore, if Jesus is merely a human descendant of David, how can David call him Lord, suggesting that he is a greater person, one superior in nature and dignity? This challenges the idea of Jesus being just the son of David and affirms his divine nature and authority.

In this weighty declaration, Jesus affirms the inspiration of the prophetic Scriptures while ending the Pharisees' futile attempts to entrap Him. Under the influence of the Holy Spirit, David acknowledges the Messiah as Lord, pointing to His superiority. By connecting the phrase in spirit with the word call, it becomes evident that David's claim goes beyond mere human descent. David's words highlight the greatness and divine nature of the Messiah, challenging any notion of Jesus being solely the son of David.

In this declaration, Jesus establishes the inspiration of the prophetic Scriptures, ending the Pharisees' attempts to trap Him. David, under the influence of the Holy Spirit, designates the Messiah as Lord, indicating His superiority. By calling Jesus Lord, David acknowledges that there is something greater about Him than mere human descent. This challenges the belief that Jesus is solely the son of David and highlights His divine nature and dignity. The phrase in spirit emphasizes the influence of the Spirit of God in David's inspired words.

Jesus' weighty declaration in this scene emphasizes the inspiration of the prophetic Scriptures, effectively ending the Pharisees' failed attempts to trap Him. David, inspired by the Holy Spirit, calls the Messiah Lord, signifying His superiority. This challenges the notion that Jesus is merely the son of David and highlights His higher nature and dignity. The phrase in spirit connects with the word call to indicate the influence of the Spirit of God in David's proclamation. It affirms that Jesus is more than just a human descendant of David.

In this scene, Jesus reveals the inspiration of the prophetic Scriptures, ending the Pharisees' attempts to trap Him. David, under the influence of the Holy Spirit, designates the Messiah as Lord, implying superiority. By connecting the phrase in spirit with the word call, it becomes clear that David saw more in the Messiah than just a human descendant. This challenges the belief that Jesus is solely the son of David, affirming his divine nature and authority.
